qas.question: Why is there a video length limit on SVCD?
What is the kilobit rate for a DVD?
How does a VCN compare to a DVD?
Why is it difficult to put more than 60 minutes on a DVD?

context: <a1_0>SVCD<a1_0/> has <b7_0>two-thirds the resolution<b7_0/> of DVD, and over 2.7 times the resolution of VCD. One CD-R disc can hold up to <a0_0><b4_0>60 minutes<b4_0/><a0_0/> of standard quality SVCD-format video. While no specific limit on SVCD video length is mandated by the specification, <b5_0>one must <a2_0>lower the video bit rate<a2_0/>, and therefore quality<b5_0/>, to accommodate very long videos. It is usually difficult to fit much more than <a3_0>100 minutes<a3_0/> of video onto one SVCD without incurring <b8_0>significant quality loss<b8_0/>, and many hardware players are unable to play video with an instantaneous bit rate lower than <b6_0>300 to 600 kilobits per second<b6_0/>.
